generif.text: P-Rex1 appears to be a coincidence detector in PtdIns(3,4,5)P3 and Gbetagamma signaling pathways that is particularly adapted to function downstream of heterotrimeric G proteins in neutrophils.
P-Rex1 is synergistically activated by PIP(3) and Gbetagamma and may act as a coincidence detector for these signaling molecules
P-Rex1 is regulated by phosphatidylinositol (3,4,5)-trisphosphate and Gbetagamma subunits
protein kinase A phosphorylates P-Rex1 andd inhibits the phosphatidylinositiol (3,4,5)-trisphosphate and Gbetagamma-mediated regulation of its activity

Endogenous P-Rex1 translocates to areas of Rac2 and cytoskeletal activation at the leading edge in response to chemoattractant stimuli in human neutrophils and that this translocation can be negatively modulated by activation of PKA and by cell adhesion.
P-Rex1 links mTOR signaling to Rac activation and cell migration
P-Rex1 membrane transport is mediated by G protein betagamma subunits and phosphoinositide 3-kinase
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)

This study has identified P-Rex1 as a Rac3-guanine nucleotide exchange factor in neuronal cells that localises to, and regulates, actin cytoskeletal dynamics at the axonal growth cone to in turn regulate neurite differentiation.
P-Rex1-dependent activation of Rac promotes prostate cancer metastasis.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
P-Rex1 is a key element in stromal cell-derived factor-1-induced angiogenic responses and signaling pathway.
S1P(1) signaling linked to cell migration is facilitated by a functional interaction with P-Rex1 via a mechanism that involves the maintenance of S1P(1) receptors at the cell membrane.
P-Rex1 is a critical component for formyl peptide receptor 1-mediated signaling leading to NADPH oxidase activation.
Clinical trial of gene-disease association and gene-environment interaction. (HuGE Navigator)
Observational study of gene-disease association and gene-environment interaction. (HuGE Navigator)
SNPs near PREX1 may contribute to T2 Diabetes susceptibility mediated through effects of adiposity in European Americans.
study reports the identification of P-Rex1, as a novel mediator in signalling by ErbB/HER receptors; correlation between high P-Rex1 expression and poor patient outcome in breast cancer was found
The P-Rex1 is highly overexpressed in human breast cancers and their derived cell lines, particularly those with high ErbB2 and ER expression.
Selective activation of Akt1 through mTORC2 and P-Rex1 regulates cancer cell migration, invasion and metastasis.
HDACs could regulate P-Rex1 gene transcription by interaction with Sp1 and by region-specific changes in histone acetylation within the P-Rex1 promoter
Demonstrate presence of P-Rex1 in platelets as well as its role in platelet secretion and aggregation induced by low-dose agonists for g-protein coupled receptors and by collagen.
We have identified a novel mechanism for direct activation of P-Rex1 through PP1alpha-dependent dephosphorylation.

Studies indicate relevance of P-Rex1 and P-Rex2a, in breast tumorigenesis, and suggest that the exchange factors Vav2 and Vav3 play synergistic roles in breast cancer by sustaining tumor growth, neoangiogenesis, and metastasis.

These data suggest that P-Rex1 has an influence on physiological migratory processes, such as invasion of cancer cells, both through effects upon classical Rac1-driven motility and a novel association with RTK signalling complexes.
Cucurbitacin I also failed to affect the activation of P-Rex1 by heregulin.
Phosphorylation of P-Rex1 at serine 1169 participates in IGF-1R signaling in breast cancer cells.
PREX1 gene promoter hypomethylation is a prognostic marker of poor patient survival.
P-REX1 promotes both PI3K/AKT and MEK/ERK signaling in breast cancer.
The P-Rex1-Rac1 interface is critical for Rac1 activation in breast cancer cells.
findings suggest a vital role of P-Rex1 signaling in CA1 LTD that is critical for social behavior and cognitive function and offer new insight into the etiology of ASDs
P-Rex1 contributes to the spatiotemporal localization of type I PKA, which tightly regulates this guanine exchange factor by a multistep mechanism.
An unexpected role for P-Rex1 and Rac1 activation in the genesis of prostate cancer stem cells and resistance to bevacizumab and sunitinib.
There is a significant association in the expression of P-Rex1 and MMP10 in human luminal breast cancer, and their co-expression is indicative of poor prognosis.
PREX1 overexpression reduced staurosporine-induced apoptosis whereas its shRNA knockdown promoted apoptosis in response to staurosporine or the anti-estrogen drug tamoxifen.
data point to multiple mechanisms of PREX1 negative regulation by PAKs within receptor tyrosine kinase and GPCR-stimulated signaling pathways

Authors suggest that control of P-Rex1 activity depends on a highly dynamic interplay among distinct signalling routes and its multisite phosphorylation is controlled by the action of different kinases.
PREX1 integrates dopamine receptor and phosphoinositide 3-kinase signaling to promote glioblastoma tumor cell invasion.

upon ligation of the T-cell antigen receptor (TCR), the TCR associates with and transactivates CXCR4 via phosphorylation of S339-CXCR4 in order to activate a PREX1-Rac1-signaling pathway that stabilizes interleukin-2(IL-2), IL-4, and IL-10 messenger RNA (mRNA) transcripts.

Data suggest that PREX1 and PREX2 share similarities in amino acid sequence, domain structure, activation by PIP(3) [phosphatidylinositol 3,4,5-triphosphate] and G-protein-coupled receptors beta/gamma subunits; expression of PREX1 and PREX2 is altered in many cancers. [REVIEW]

a novel role for GRK2 as a target of TCR signaling that is responsible for TCR-induced transactivation of CXCR4 and TCR-CXCR4 complex formation that signals via PI3Kgamma/PREX1 to mediate cytokine production.
GTPase-deficient G-ALPHA-qQL and Galpha13QL variants formed stable complexes with G protein beta gamma, impairing its interaction with P-REX1.

type I PKA regulatory subunits (RIalpha) interact with phosphatidylinositol 3,4,5-trisphosphate-dependent Rac exchange factor 1 (P-REX1), a chemotactic Rac guanine exchange factor (RacGEF). RIalpha CNB-B domain is critical for the interaction with P-REX1, which was increased in RIalpha mutants, such as the acrodysostosis-associated mutant, that activate P-REX1 at basal cAMP levels.
PREX1 is a favorable variable of prognosis for breast cancer patients.
PREX1 drives spontaneous bone dissemination of ER+ breast cancer cells.
A multidomain assembly is key to the regulation of P-Rex1.
The first DEP domain of the RhoGEF P-Rex1 autoinhibits activity and contributes to membrane binding.
Overexpression of PREX1 in oral squamous cell carcinoma indicates poor prognosis.
Gbetagamma recruits and activates P-Rex1 via two independent binding interfaces.
Identification of Rac guanine nucleotide exchange factors promoting Lgl1 phosphorylation in glioblastoma.
Structure of the metastatic factor P-Rex1 reveals a two-layered autoinhibitory mechanism.
Silencing Rac1 and Prex1 Inhibit Epithelial-Mesenchymal Transition in Human Gastric Cancer Cells Induced by Transforming Growth Factor-beta1.
PREX1 improves homeostatic proliferation to maintain a naive CD4+ T cell compartment in older age.
Structural and dynamic changes in P-Rex1 upon activation by PIP3 and inhibition by IP4.

BP.term: regulation of small GTPase mediated signal transduction
positive regulation of substrate adhesion-dependent cell spreading

interpro.desc: Guanine-nucleotide dissociation stimulator, CDC24, conserved site

name: phosphatidylinositol-3,4,5-trisphosphate dependent Rac exchange factor 1

kegg.name: Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus infection - Homo sapiens (human)

reactome.name: Cell death signalling via NRAGE, NRIF and NADE
Signaling by Rho GTPases, Miro GTPases and RHOBTB3

summary: The protein encoded by this gene acts as a guanine nucleotide exchange factor for the RHO family of small GTP-binding proteins (RACs).  It has been shown to bind to and activate RAC1 by exchanging bound GDP for free GTP. The encoded protein, which is found mainly in the cytoplasm, is activated by phosphatidylinositol-3,4,5-trisphosphate and the beta-gamma subunits of heterotrimeric G proteins. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
